text: About a nice inequality Cezar Lupu, Cosmin Pohoat¸a In [1.](page 75), Gabriel Dospinescu, Mircea Lascu and Marian Tetiva gave two solutions to the following inequality: Let a, b, c be three nonnegative real numbers. Show that: a 2 + b 2 + c 2 + 2abc + 3 ≥ (1 + a)(1 + b)(1 + c). (1) On the Mathlinks Forum, Darij Grinberg proved a sharper inequality: For any a, b, c positive real numbers, the following inequality holds: a 2 + b 2 + c 2 + 2abc + 1 ≥ 2(ab + bc + ca). (2) The solution given by Darij on the Mathlinks Forum is based on Schur’s in- equality written in the form: 2(ab + bc + ca) − (a2 + b 2 + c 2) ≤ 9abc a + b + c (3) and AM-GM, 2abc + 1 = abc + abc + 1 ≥ 3 3√a2b2c2 (4) From (3) and (4), the inequality (2) reduces to: 3 3√a2b2c2 ≥ 9abc a + b + c , (5) which is equivalent to a + b + c ≥ 3 3√abc, which is plain AM-GM. Vasile Cˆartoaje gave another solution to (2). (see [2], page 17). In this paper, we shall give another solution to (2) via convex functions using Popoviciu’s inequality. Theorem 1. (Tiberiu Popoviciu, 1965) Let I be an interval and f : I → R a convex function. Then for any x, y, z ∈ I the following inequality is valid: f (x)+f (y)+f (z)+3f ( x + y + z 3 ) ≥ 2 [f ( x + y 2 ) + f ( y + z 2 ) + f ( z + x 2 )] . A simple calculation of derivatives shows that f is convex. By Popoviciu’s inequality, we obtain: exp(2x) + exp(2y) + exp(2z) + 3 exp ( 2(x + y + z) 3 ) ≥ 2[exp(x + y) + exp(y + z) + exp(z + x)]. which is equivalent to: exp 2(x) + exp2(y) + exp2(z) + 3 3√ exp2(x) · exp2(y) · exp2(z) ≥ 2[exp(x) · exp(y) + exp(y) · exp(z) + exp(z) · exp(x)]. Now, denote exp(x) = a > 0, exp(y) = b > 0, exp(z) = c > 0. We get the inequality: a 2 + b 2 + c 2 + 3 3√a2b2c2 ≥ 2(ab + bc + ca). The next application is from the Romanian Junior Selection test for Balkan Olympiad 2005 and it was proposed by the ﬁrst author of this paper. A3. Let x, y, z three positive reals such that (x + y)(y + z)(z + x) = 1. Show that xy + yz + zx ≤ 3 4 . (12) Solution. We put x + y = c, z + x = b and y + z = a. It follows that x = b + c − a 2 , y = c + a − b 2 and z = a + b − c 2 . Now, we only need to prove that ∑ cyc (b + c − a)(c + a − b) ≤ 3. It was proposed by Hojoo Lee at the Asia-Paciﬁc Olympiad in 2004. A4. Let a, b, c three positive reals. Show that (a2 + 2)(b 2 + 2)(c 2 + 2) ≥ 9(ab + bc + ca). (14) Solution.
